content.description: This is the crack system on the left side of the slab.

This is one of my favorite routes at Harmel's even if it has bolts close to the ground. The bolts were at least placed on lead and hand drilled. Start at a short and shallow corner at the base of the arete.

Climb up to the 1st bolt above a stiff little mantel. Continue up to the bulging face, and clip the second bolt. Surmount the bulge on hidden holds, and climb up to the bolted anchors. Be wary of the flakes on the edge of the arete, they are a wee bit crunchy and have diminished in size over the years from rough handling. The loss of these flakes would make this a much harder climb.
content.location:
This ascends the arete between

Baby Face

and

Air Conditioner

corner.

content.description:
Crystal Staircase is one of my favorite routes at Harmels because of its unique beauty. It is the quite stellar band of crystals that sweeps up and left from the base of

Tony's Tango

and ends at the chains where Toys and Left Hand converge. The transition from the top of the staircase and into the cracks leading to the anchors is the somewhat heady crux.
content.protection: The pro is sparse but sufficient with a good eye for pro. This is probably not a good lead for a beginner, but it is an awesome toprope for anyone.
content.location:
Start the same as

Tony's Tango

, then veer up and right following the crystal band.

content.description:
On lead, you can go right above the first face and pull a small overhang that can take protection. An interesting variation (5.10) stays left on the second face (off the diagonal ramp).  Follow the face to the chains at the top of

Tony's Trango

and

Left Hand Crack

.
content.protection: Draws and small stoppers and cams.
content.location:
This climb is to the right of

Tony's Trango

and the left of

Left Hand Crack

.  It goes right up the center of the face.  There is (only) one bolt about 25 feet up.

content.description:
This ascends the obvious crack / ramp in the broken area of the 1st buttress between the big roof and

Tony's Tango

.

It is a good beginner's outing. The bolts at the top allow a wide variety of toprope adventures.

This was my first climb at Harmels back in 1975. It is a sweet corner/crack climb with good pro and an intriquing variety of techniques to deal with. As the name implies, locals regularly 3rd class this route often down from the ledge, but don't let their having it wired allow you take Solo Crack for granted. It is full value. Many options to continue exist, the classic finish being up

Aqua Dog

.

Solo Crack is a fine first or early lead for the aspiring trad afficianado.
content.protection: A standard Taylor trad rack. This route tops out on the same ledge that Air Conditioner does. Trad anchors are easy to set up here. There are fixed anchors to the right near the top to set up a TR.
content.location:
Around the corner and up a short scramble to the left of

Tony's Tango

lies the cool V slot of Solo Crack.

content.description:
Aquadog is a fantastic last pitch to the top finish for any of the routes from

Solo Crack

all the way to Air Conditioner Crack. A combination of wide crack/OW and face climbing leads to a unique topout. When looking at it from below, this is a fierce looking, wide crack above a smooth slab that swoops up and right through a roof.
content.protection: Solid gear - as much or as little as you want - can be found the whole way. There is no fixed gear on this route.
content.location:
This is the last pitch to the very top of the buttress that has the routes from

Solo Crack

to Air Conditioner on it.
